content.text:
# Draft:Timeline of the 2000 United States presidential election

This is a timeline of major events leading up to, during, and following, the 2000 United States presidential election, which took place on November 7, 2000.
1996
* November 5: Bill Clinton won the 1996 United States presidential election, defeating Republican Bob Dole, and being reelected for a second term.
1997
* January 9: In a joint session of the United States Congress, the results of the Electoral College were formally counted. In his role as President of the Senate, Vice President Al Gore read the results and declared Bill Clinton the winner of the 1996 presidential election.
* January 20: Bill Clinton and Al Gore were inaugurated for a second term as president and vice president of the United States, respectively. This was the last presidential inauguration of the 20th century.
1998
* January 27: BBC speculated on a potential Gore presidency amidst the Clintonâ€“Lewinsky scandal.
1999
January 1999
* January 25: Bill Bradley, former professional basketball player and former Democratic Senator from New Jersey, announced his candidacy for the presidential election.
March 1999
* March 9: During an interview with CNN's Late Edition with Wolf Blitzer, Gore stated, "During my service in the United States Congress I took the initiative in creating the internet." Following the interview, a widely spread urban legend that Gore claimed to have invented the internet, began.
April 1999
* April 13: John McCain, Republican Senator from Arizona, who had previously postponed his announcement due to the Kosovo War, declared his intention to run for the presidency.
June 1999
* June 12: George W. Bush, the Governor of Texas and the eldest son of former president George H. W. Bush, declared his interest in running for president, and entered the Republican primaries.
* June 16: Gore launched his presidential campaign, entering the Democratic primaries.
September 1999
* September 21: Alan Keyes, former Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination.
December 1999
* December 30: The Bush Campaign announced a record-breaking $67 million raised from over 171,000 people, throughout 1999.
2000
September 2000
* September 14: Gore poked fun at the internet controversy on the Late Show with David Letterman.
November 2000
* November 7: On election night, the winner of the election was unclear.
2001
* January 20: George W. Bush and Dick Cheney were inaugurated as the 43th president and 46th vice president of the United States respectively.
See also
* Timeline of the Bill Clinton presidency
* Timeline of the George W. Bush presidency
References
